title: 110_s1891
content: IMMUNITY FOR REPORTS OF SUSPECTED TERRORIST ACTIVITY OR SUSPICIOUS BEHAVIOR AND RESPONSE. Immunity is granted to individuals who report suspected terrorist activity or suspicious behavior in good faith and based on reasonable suspicion. They are protected from civil liability under any law for making such reports. However, this immunity does not apply if the report is known to be false or made recklessly. Additionally, immunity is also provided for the response to such reports. False reports are not protected under immunity if known to be false or made recklessly. Authorized officials responding to covered activity in good faith have qualified immunity from civil liability. An authorized official responding in good faith to reported activity is immune from civil liability under applicable law. Authorized officials are immune from civil liability under Federal, State, and local law if they take reasonable action in good faith to respond to reported activity. This immunity does not affect their ability to assert any defense, privilege, or immunity that would otherwise be available. Additionally, it does not impact any existing defenses. Any person or authorized official found to be immune from civil liability under this section is also immune from attorney fees and costs. In this section, authorized officials are immune from civil liability if they take reasonable action in good faith. They can still assert any defense available and are entitled to recover attorney fees and costs. The term "authorized official" includes employees or agents responsible for security in passenger transportation systems. The term "authorized official" includes employees or agents responsible for security in passenger transportation systems, as well as officers from relevant government departments and law enforcement officers. The term "covered activity" refers to specific security-related responsibilities. The term "covered activity" refers to any suspicious transaction, activity, or occurrence involving a passenger transportation system or vehicle that may indicate a violation of law related to threats to passenger safety or security. The term "passenger transportation" refers to public transportation, over-the-road bus transportation, and school bus services, involving suspicious activities that may indicate a threat to passenger safety or security. Passenger transportation includes public transportation, over-the-road bus transportation, school bus transportation, intercity passenger rail transportation, transportation of passenger vessels, and regularly scheduled waterborne transportation. Passenger transportation system includes transportation of passenger vessels, regularly scheduled waterborne transportation service, and air transportation of passengers. The term "passenger transportation system" refers to entities providing passenger transportation using vehicles. The term "vehicle" is defined as in title 18, United States Code. This section will be effective immediately upon enactment and applies to activities and claims thereafter.
